newsitem.title: UK: BOE says not seeking overnight credit outside EMU.
newsitem.headline: BOE says not seeking overnight credit outside EMU.

text.p: The Bank of England would not seek access to overnight credit if Britain opted out of a single European currency, Bank of England Governor Eddie George said.

"We're not seeking to be allowed to create credit overnight, all we're seeking to do is to be able to extend intraday credit in order to avoid gridlock within the realtime gross settlement payments system," he said at a press conference on Monday.

But he said that the 'outs' -- countries opting out of European Economic and Monetary Union -- must have equal access to intraday credit in order to ensure the effective functioning of payments systems.
George said it was possible that there could be spillover from intraday credit to overnight credit and said that should be penalised just as it is in any national system.
""We're not asking for something that can have significant impact on monetary conditions," he said. "The monetary union area has to be able to control the monetary conditions within that area."
George was speaking at a news conference at which senior Bank officials presented a report entitled "Practical Issues Arising from the Introduction of the Euro."
